These flags are passed to `LockTime()`. Adding a bunch of other flag definitions which are not used by `LockTime()` would only cause confusion, I think.
Any compiler more recent than the 1960's will evaluate an expression consisting entirely of literals at compile time. In this case I prefer the clarity of specifying what is being tested in-line.

It seems to me BIP 113 is actually a hardfork being treated as a softfork, at least how it currently stands, and this PR will potentially produce invalid blocks. Suggest reverting it and thinking through revising the BIP to be an actual softfork.

Assume you have a perfect sequence of blocks, where block at height N has timestamp N*600.

Block 12 has timestamp 7200. Its mediantimepast() is 3600. It is valid as 7200 is >= 3601.

A transaction has nLockTime 5000. It is invalid currently in block 12, as 5000 is below 7200. Post BIP113, it is valid, as it is above 3600.

@sipa No, we're being silly.   The requirement is that the txlocktime be _above_ $thing.  Under the old rule $thing was blocktime,  under this rule it is MTP.   Since blocktime is already required to be greater than MTP,  it's fine.

5000 < 7200   so that transaction is valid now.   It is > 3600 so it wouldn't be accepted by MTP.

> The requirement is that the txlocktime be above $thing. Under the old rule $thing was blocktime.

So the requirement is : blocktime < txlocktime
[blocktime]7200 < [txlocktime]5000  evaluate to false so the transaction is invalid now.

Sorry for being late, but could someone confirm my understanding of BIP113's implications below?

First, before BIP113 goes BIP9 ACTIVE, with respect to time based lock times, these must be true:

1. `nLockTime < block.GetBlockTime()`
1. `previousBlock->GetMedianTimePast() < block.GetBlockTime() <= GetAdjustedTime() + 2 * 60 * 60`

In other words, we currently have this for Core nodes that must be true:

1. `nLockTime < range(previousBlock->GetMedianTimePast() + 1, some variable end time)`
1. `(sixth highest block time of the previous 11 blocks) < block.GetBlockTime() <= ("node specific perspective of now" +- < 70 minute peer time offset) + 120 minutes`

This work changes changes the first item to be:

1. `nLockTime < previousBlock->GetMedianTimePast()`

With the implications being:

1. we're removing the uncertainty of the node specific and variable valid time range calculation `> previousBlock->GetMedianTimePast()`
1. we're making mempool policy, and thus relay policy, more restrictive for lock time transactions because it is bound by MTP instead of adjusted time
1. there is a notion that the sixth highest block time of the previous 11 blocks is going to be about an hour before "now", and thus take about an hour longer before lock time transactions are considered final/relayable. I inferred this from reading https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0113.mediawiki#compatibility. I wanted to confirm that that is the reasoning, since it seems plausible, but also seemed to contradict https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/6566#issue-101544600 "Users can compensate for this change by simply adding an hour (3600 seconds) to their time-based lock times." I may have just read that differently than it was intended, but it seems like they'd want to subtract an hour to achieve roughly the same point in time that the transaction would become final.
